content.description: Funky moves off the ground lead to jugs just above. Pass left of the tree, then step right and pull a few crimps (crux). Continue up the crack system to the top ledge.Â
content.protection: Either bring a long static rope, or trad gear (.75 - 2) to make a top rope anchor. Hint: there's a horn you can sling as a leg of the anchor about 15 feet behind and to the right of the trad gear placements if desired.
content.location: One hundred feet right of Trundle Bundle in the center of a tall, vertical face. Start at the shallow left-facing V-groove in the center of this face. Alternatively, start at the crack 10 feet right and work across the horizontal finger cracks for a more muscley and less technical start.

content.description:
A good, short route. Would be good for an early lead.

 Up the series of flakes to a ledge, then onto the top.
content.location: Just to the left of a corner with a tree growing out of it, to the right of Fancy Feet

content.description: A series of thin 5.11d/12a moves lead to a decent hold out left about 25' up.  Step right, then make a series of powerful layback moves.  A strenuous, but critical, number 4 nut protects the lower part of the crux, while a number 1 tcu protects the upper part.  Continue up the crack (easier) to the top of the cliff.
content.location: Begin 12' to the left of 'Elusive Bastard' at the base of a thin crack.  This is the highest part of the wall and overhangs about 5'.

content.description: Begin at the bottom of the left facing corner.  Fun moves lead past the corner to a no handed rest.  Step right around the corner and easier climbing gains the top.
content.protection: Standard rack and probably some long slings.  Webbing for an anchor.
content.location: Located in a shaded area on the far left.  The left facing corner.

content.description: Begin at the bottom of a flared section.  Make technical moves working through the flare to a horizontal about 12' off the deck.  Place a critical #00 TCU in the horizontal at the top of the flare and make a series of layback moves, fighting the barn door, up to a hidden hold.  That was the crux.  Consider yourself lucky if you fall and do not hit the ground.  You can get gear in the layback section, but it is extremely tough and you would essentially be placing it blind.  Gain a ledge and easier climbing up a nice crack leads to the top.
content.location: About 25' to the right of Main Attraction.  Begin at the base of a flared section.

content.description: The most prominent crack at the crag, also known as 'The Whipping Post'.  Begin up the crack to a horizontal at 10'.  Continue past a technical section to the bottom of a flare at another horizontal, you can get a no handed rest here by utilizing a knee bar.  Through the flared section to yet another horizontal.  About 1.5' above this, strenuously slot a #4 nut to protect the crux.  Make a delicate move and up to a fixed anchor.  Fun and somewhat technical.  Popular.
content.protection: All of the pro is bomb provided you know how to look for gear placements.  Standard rack. Fixed anchor at the top.
content.location: Middle of the crag.  Look for a flared section 2/3 of the way up.

climbs.name: Egg!
climbs.fa: Gunnar Nurme & Izzy de Buy Wenniger, September 2019

content.description: A slightly shorter and dirtier version of Trundle Bundle. Not an amazing route, but it does have some fun moves, is well protected, and is a good easier addition to the crag. Follows a system of cracks and flakes past a large ledge at mid-height to a rap anchor on a tree
content.protection: Single rack. Be wary of a slightly loose large block/flake halfway up
content.location: 10-15 feet to the right of the start of Trundle Bundle. To the right of a left facing mossy corner with a tree growing out of it. Starts on a face with twin cracks

content.description: This route is good and often wet, though it can still be climbed if the 2nd half is damp.  A bouldery start leads to a horizontal and a better section of the crack.  Work the crack to another horizontal and up to the top.
content.location: About 30' to the left of the Main Attraction.

content.description: A small crag with few good traditional climbs located just north of the Adirondacks.  Frequented by St. Lawrence students who did most of the establishing.  Beautiful area especially in the fall.
